bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Jessie Daniel Ames, July 3, 1942

div1.p: Hench informs Ames that he has been called-up for active duty. He poses numerous questions about the material she has sent to him. He expresses his desire to paint an accurate portrayal of Ames' contribution to the yellow fever experiments.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Jessie Daniel Ames, July 3, 1942
div1.opener:
July 3, 1942
Mrs. Jessie Daniels Ames
710 Standard Bldg.
Atlanta, Georgia
My dear Mrs. Ames:
div1.p:
I am about to enter the Medical Corps of the army, presumably with
the rank of Lieutenant Colonel, as chief of the medical service of a large
station hospital. I have been so busy getting together a group of men for this
hospital that I have been until now unable to write to you. I have finally had
the photostatic copies made of many of the items in your portfolio and I am so
grateful to you for sending them. I do not expect to enter active service for
about three more weeks and would be very grateful if you could
1. Send me the twenty-two or twenty-three original fever charts
which you have of Dean, Lazear, etc. I am anxious to study them and make photo-
static copies of them.
2. Regarding the letter of February 27 from T.D. Berry to Dr. Ames,
do you have a copy of the reply from the editor of the Journal of the A.M.A.?
I should appreciate your further comments about Berry's contention that Dr. Ames'
case of yellow fever was an experimental one. Who was Berry? I can't place him.
3. Do you have any copies, carbon copies or otherwise, of Dr. Ames'
answers to Dr. Berry's letter? Is Dr. Berry living or if not do you know the
address of his survivors?
4. In Berry's letter of March 20, Dr. Ames is quoted at the bottom
of the first page as follows: “The fact that I was one of the unreported ex-
perimental cases is established only by the press reports of which I have no
acquaintance.” I don't know quite how to interpret this. Was Dr. Ames inferring
that his case was really experimental or not?
5. In the second part of your inclosure XVIII in Dr. Ames' letter
to the Surgeon General dated December 30, 1901, requesting all the data on all
the charts and clinical records of various yellow fever cases, I would appreciate
it greatly if you would send me as much of this as you have by registered mail
or insured express. I will study it promptly, with your permission copy some of
it promptly and return it to you definitely before I leave for service.
6. The letter and enclosure VI from O'Reilly to Dr. Ames indicates
that Dr. Ames had the original charts and that O'Reilly had copies made and re-
turned the originals to Dr. Ames. Does this refer to the fever charts which
you still have?
7. Your label on enclosure XXX suggests that there were several
reprints present and the reprints were not present in the portfolio when I re-
ceived it.
8. In your letter to me of April 2, under your answer to my second
question, you state that Dr. Ames' chart shows that he was sick for nine, not
three or four days. I am especially anxious to have a copy of his chart. Would
you lend it to me with the others?
9. Were you able to find Dr. Ames' map of the infected district
near Camp Columbia among his sister's possessions? You were kind enough to say
that you would write to her. I shall appreciate greatly if you would send me
her name and address. I should like to send her one of my reprints on the
yellow fever story.
Mrs. Jessie D. Ames
- 2-
July 3, 1942
10. I showed the group photographs (your enclosure VIII) to Dr.
Cook, Mr. Lambert, General Truby and one or two others but they were unable
to recognize any of the men except Dr. Ames. Obviously it was not taken at
Camp Columbia or Camp Lazear. Do you know about the approximate date when Dr.
Ames started to wear a moustache? This would help to identify the time when
certain photographs were taken.
11. You mentioned that a cousin of yours in New Orleans might have
some Havana newspapers or a copy of the “New Orleans Picayune” for July 30, 1905.
I would appreciate it greatly if I could have a photostatic copy of that article
if you are able to do so.
12. Do you have another copy of your enclosure No. XX. I gather
that you do not from the heading on this enclosure.

Let me express my deep appreciation for your lending me this in-
valuable material. I only hope that I can do justice to all the men concerned
and give an accurate portrayal of Dr. Ames' real contribution. You have helped
me tremendously and any further help you can give me will be greatly appreciated.
Perhaps when I reach my military station I can still carry on this study as a
hobby and I would appreciate the privilege of writing you further.
div1.closer: Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
